original_title: Sri Lanka’s central town Akurana starts body checking at mosques after security threat
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Muslims in Sri Lanka’s central town of Akurana started checking devotees who came for mosques from Tuesday (18) after top police officials had informed them to beef up security due to an unverified information of a possible attack to Islamic religious places during the prayers in the holy month of Ramzan, officials and people in Akurana said.

Police officials at a meeting with the mosque committees in Akurana have said they have got information on possible attacks on mosques in Akurana. The Police Spokesman was not immediately available for comment.
“They said it could or could not be true, but better to be prepared at community level,” Isthihar Ahamed, former chairman of Akurana Pradeshiya Sabha, told EconomyNext.

“The police told that they could assist in the security at the Akurana town area and requested mosque committees to help them at individual mosques to ensure the security. So mosque committees have come up with some recommendations.”
Two other sources said the recommendations include body check on both men and women devotees.
“This could be a conspiracy theory by anyone. But when government officials who are in charge of law and order tell us we can’t neglect,” one of the two sources said.
“It could be due to high businesses in the town or some differences in ideologies of the people.”
Military Spokesman Ravi Herath confirmed that the army has been requested to assist in security.
“Nothing has happened so far. The police received the message  yesterday evening and they asked our support if something happens,” Herath told EconomyNext.
“Accordingly we had some platoons stand by. However, there was no threat and nothing has happened so far in the area.”

Sri Lankans are sensitive to security threats to religious places due to attacks on Buddhist temples and mosques during 26-year civil war between the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) and the government army as well as the Easter Sunday attack which targeted Churches and killed mainly Catholic devotees in 2019.
The latest threats come before the 4th year anniversary of Easter Sunday attack on Friday (21). (Colombo/April19/2023)
